categories.name: Formal Fallacies
categories.description: Errors in the logical structure of an argument

fallacies.label: Non Sequitur
fallacies.definition: The conclusion doesn't logically follow from the premises
fallacies.example: The Founders wore wigs, therefore their arguments about liberty are invalid.

fallacies.label: False Dilemma
fallacies.definition: Presenting only two options when more exist
fallacies.example: Either we submit entirely to Parliament or face total chaos - there is no middle ground.

fallacies.label: Affirming the Consequent
fallacies.definition: If A then B; B is true, therefore A must be true
fallacies.example: If Britain oppresses us, we'll resist. We're resisting, therefore Britain oppresses us.

categories.name: Informal Fallacies
categories.description: Arguments that are logically unsound for lack of well-grounded premises

fallacies.label: Ad Hominem
fallacies.definition: Attacking the person making the argument rather than the argument itself
fallacies.example: Hamilton is a bastard from the Caribbean, so his financial plan must be wrong.

fallacies.label: Appeal to Authority
fallacies.definition: Citing authority instead of providing actual reasoning
fallacies.example: King George says we must obey Parliament, and he is our divinely appointed monarch, so we must obey.

fallacies.label: Appeal to Emotion
fallacies.definition: Manipulating emotions (fear, pity, anger) rather than using logical reasoning
fallacies.example: Think of the children who will suffer if we break from Britain! How can you be so heartless?

fallacies.label: Straw Man
fallacies.definition: Misrepresenting an opponent's position to make it easier to attack
fallacies.example: The loyalists want us to be slaves forever, worshipping the King as a god.

fallacies.label: Slippery Slope
fallacies.definition: Claiming A will inevitably lead to Z without evidence for the causal chain
fallacies.example: If we allow any taxation, soon they'll take everything we own and enslave us all.

fallacies.label: False Analogy
fallacies.definition: Comparing two things that aren't actually comparable
fallacies.example: Just as a child must obey their father, so must the colonies obey the mother country.

fallacies.label: Begging the Question
fallacies.definition: Using the conclusion as a premise (circular reasoning)
fallacies.example: We must resist tyranny because tyrants must be resisted.

fallacies.label: Red Herring
fallacies.definition: Introducing an irrelevant topic to distract from the original argument
fallacies.example: Yes, Parliament taxed us unfairly, but what about the threat from French Canada?

fallacies.label: Tu Quoque (You Too)
fallacies.definition: Accusing the opponent of hypocrisy instead of addressing their argument
fallacies.example: Jefferson says all men are created equal, but he owns slaves, so his argument is worthless.

fallacies.label: Appeal to Tradition
fallacies.definition: Something is right because it's always been done this way
fallacies.example: We've been subjects of the British Crown for 150 years - we should continue to be.

fallacies.label: Bandwagon
fallacies.definition: Something is true because many people believe it
fallacies.example: Most colonists still support the King, so remaining loyal must be the right choice.
